Award.AwardTitle: Mousterian Socioeconomic Organization in Southeastern Europe

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most interesting questions in Paleolithic archaeology today is what research in such early periods can tell us about the origins of modern human behavior and culture. With support from the National Science Foundation, Dr. Robert Whallon will lead an international team of scholars in an investigation of this question at a large and important Neanderthal site in southeastern Europe.

There are currently great differences of opinion among Paleolithic archaeologists about whether the behavior and culture of our nearest biological relatives, the Neanderthals, was primitive and limited compared to us, or whether they show the beginnings of essentially modern behavior and culture. Recently, it has been proposed that the division of labor, universally characteristic of ethnographically known human hunter-gatherers, did not exist in Neanderthal societies, but was part of the socioeconomic systems of the modern human populations that spread from the eastern Mediterranean throughout Europe. It was presumably the greater effectiveness of an economic system based on the division of labor that allowed modern human populations to expand and replace the Neanderthals.

This project will evaluate this proposal by investigating the organization of Neanderthal subsistence economy and society over a long sequence of changing environmental conditions. Specifically, it will test the hypothesis that Neanderthals pursued large game hunting in warmer climates by bridging gaps between successful hunts by storing meat that was preserved by smoking and drying over fire. In colder climates, with little or no forest available for fuel, Neanderthals were unable to avoid unpredictable gaps in foraging success in this way, and were therefore subject to food stress and fluctuations in population. In these conditions, Neanderthal populations would have been comparatively small and sparse.

The location of this project is the site of Crvena Stijena, a large rock shelter on the western border of Montenegro. Crvena Stijena contains a sequence of undisturbed Middle Paleolithic archaeological deposits at least 9 m in depth, estimated to range in age from approximately 40,000 to 150,000 BP. This sequence probably represents the longest record of Neanderthal archaeology yet discovered in the southeastern Europe. Neanderthal economic and social organization in the occupations represented by these deposits will be reconstructed through coordinated studies of their hearths, the animal bones, the stone tools, and other remains, conducted by a series of expert specialists.

The broader impacts of this project include significant components of teaching and training, especially of students in Balkan countries. American students are closely involved in this project as well, being trained in Paleolithic archaeology, and given opportunities for developing undergraduate honors theses and doctoral dissertation research. In the course of their participation, American students are also exposed to an international and multi-cultural experience that enhances their understanding of the world and of different cultures. In addition, the project will contribute significantly to the development of the research infrastructure in Montenegro, helping to build up comparative research and teaching collections in several research centers and museums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate how our nearest prehistoric European relatives, the Neanderthals, lived through glacial and interglacial climate changes until anatomically modern humans expanded into Europe and displaced them. In particular, it is curious how Neanderthals survived by living on a diet that previous studies have shown probably consisted primarily of meat. Hunting to provide meat for food is a very uncertain subsistence strategy. Hunting success is so uncertain that it results in frequent periods of food scarcity and often total absence. Depending primarily on hunting for food would have put the Neanderthals at great risk of starving to death and thus becoming extinct.

One plausible way in which they might have lived by hunting and coped with frequent periods of food shortage or failure might have been to prepare meat for storage by drying and smoking it — practices known from many times and places and which continue into the present day. Stored meats could have allowed the Neanderthals to bridge over the critical periods of potential starvation and to survive them successfully.

This project set out to test this possibility by excavating a large rock shelter site, Crvena Stijena, in Montenegro, southeastern Europe, where there was a long sequence of Middle Paleolithic (Neanderthal) occupations within which there were numerous and varied remains of fire. Some of these fire features were small hearths of “campfire” size and structure, but others showed evidence for long and intense burning over extensive areas. It was thought that these large areas of fire might have been for the drying and smoking of meat for storage.

Excavations did uncover much evidence of Neanderthal occupation, but they also ran into massive quantities of geologically deposited sterile sediments and very large rocks fallen from the roof of the rock shelter. This significantly slowed down the pace of excavation such that, even using large backhoes and trucks to remove over 5000 cubic yards of sterile material, only the upper layers of the Middle Paleolithic sequence could be excavated and analyzed. These layers contained just the familiar, “campfire” type hearths, so that it was not possible to test the idea that the extensive areas of burning seen in the profiles of lower layers might have been for meat drying and smoking. Even in the upper layers with their small hearths, however, analysis of the bones of the animals they hunted (almost exclusively red deer—American elk) showed evidence of meat stripping. This kind of evidence is quite characteristic of the preparation of meat for drying and smoking, but the idea that this was done on a large scale using extensive areas of fire remains to be tested.

The project was able to clearly date these upper layers to approximately 38,000-44,000 years ago. The lower layers that could not be fully excavated were sampled from a profile cut and were dated in the range of 65,000-70,000 years ago. Some layers far down near the base of the Middle Paleolithic sequence are of course older, but no absolute dates were obtained for them.

From the excavations accomplished by this project, a picture emerges clearly of small groups of Neanderthal hunters living for relatively short periods of time at this site. They obtained raw materials for their stone tools from outcrops that can be found at many places within 15 km of the site. From the surrounding forests they chose almost only pine wood for their fires, around which they sat, made and used tools, ate, probably dried and smoked at least some of their meat, and undoubtedly also slept.

Although it is satisfying to be able to reconstruct this much of the life of the Neanderthals who frequented this shelter, it would be very desirable to examine the unusually large fire features in the lower layers and to see if they were indeed specialized for the drying and smoking of meat in preparation for storage. The project has well prepared the site for further excavation that should eventually answer this question, and continuing research to that end has already begun. It therefore can be expected that an answer to this intriguing question will be forthcoming in the future.

Project results were communicated to the public regularly by newspaper, radio, and television interviews and appearances, as well as publications and formal lectures. In addition, the project managed to provide training to over 20 students, many of which were stimulated to pursue higher degrees in prehistoric archaeology and related specialties. About half of these students are either currently in graduate degree programs, or have already finished a doctoral degree.
